title: Vortex-induced vibration of circular cylinder
text:
When a fluid encounters a bluff body, such as a cylinder, it cannot follow the sharp curvature of the surface. This leads to boundary layer separation, where the flow detaches and forms two distinct shear layers. At low Reynolds numbers, these layers remain stable, but as the velocity increases, they begin to interact and roll up into discrete, concentrated vortices.
Crucially, these vortices do not shed simultaneously. Instead, they detach in an alternating, periodic fashion, creating the Von Kármán vortex street: a staggered trail of swirling fluid that can persist for many diameters downstream. The frequency of this shedding (\(f_s\)) is predictable and is defined by the non-dimensional Strouhal Number (St): \(f_s=\frac{St U}{D}\)
where U is the flow velocity and D is the cylinder diameter.






Figure 1: Vortex shedding behind Alexander Selkirk Island in the southern Pacific Ocean, from NASA.





While this is a fundamental problem in fluid mechanics, we encounter its effects daily. A common example is the high-pitched “whistling” or “humming” produced by a car antenna at highway speeds. This sound is the acoustic signature of vortex shedding; as the air flows past the thin rod, the alternating vortices create pressure fluctuations that vibrate the air. This happens because as a vortex is “born” on one side of the cylinder, it creates a local region of high-velocity, low-pressure fluid. This generates a net lift force that pulls the cylinder toward the vortex. As the next vortex sheds from the opposite side, the pressure drop shifts, and the lift force reverses direction.
If the cylinder is rigid and fixed, it simply experiences these fluctuating loads as fatigue or noise. However, if the structure is elastic or mounted on springs (such as a car antenna, a bridge cable, or an offshore riser), this periodic forcing begins to move the structure.
When the shedding frequency (\(f_s\)) nears the natural frequency of the structure (\(f_n\)), the fluid and the structure begin to synchronize. The shedding frequency can actually shift to match the structural frequency, leading to a state called lock-in. The result is Vortex-Induced Vibrations (VIV): high-amplitude, self-sustaining oscillations that can lead to rapid structural failure.

title: Urban Wind in San Carlos de Bariloche
text:
Anyone who has visited Bariloche is familiar with the Bariloche Center building (Google Maps). Built in the 1970s, this ten-story concrete monolith stands in stark contrast to the traditional mountain village aesthetic of the Centro Cívico just meters away.
Positioned almost perpendicular to the region’s predominant winds, this massive slab acts as a giant blockage, forcing the air to accelerate as it tries to navigate around the structure. Local pedestrians know this effect all too well: even on days with only a slight breeze, the way the building disrupts and funnels the air creates intense, localized gusts at street level.
As shown in the wind rose below, the frequency of these high-velocity events is directly tied to the dominant Western and North-Western wind directions hitting the building’s broad face.






Figure 1: Wind rose illustrating wind direction frequency at the Bariloche city center, with data sourced from Global Wind Atlas.





This brings up the question: How much does the Bariloche Center building really impact street-level wind gusts? We will answer that by using CFD tools to simulate the wind in the surrounding blocks and observing the resulting velocity fields.

title: Urban Wind in San Carlos de Bariloche
text:
Simulation details
To capture the complexity of the urban terrain, the topography of the ground and all 3D buildings were exported from OpenStreetMap and processed in AutoCAD to generate the necessary STL surfaces. The computational mesh was then generated using OpenFOAM’s snappyHexMesh utility, with significant refinement applied near building surfaces to accurately capture flow separation and corner vortices. Two mesh levels were developed for this study: a baseline low-resolution mesh of approximately 800k cells for initial solver validation, and a production high-resolution mesh of 4M cells for the final analysis.
The simulations were conducted using the simpleFoam solver for steady-state incompressible flow, utilizing the \(k-\epsilon\) turbulence model. To represent the incoming wind, an atmBoundaryLayerInletVelocity condition was applied at the inlet. This condition modeled the atmospheric boundary layer by utilizing a design wind speed of 36 km/h and the most frequent direction (West-northwest). These parameters were derived from Global Wind Atlas data to establish a realistic velocity profile that reflects the characteristic Patagonian winds of the region.







Figure 2: Surface mesh refinement on the Bariloche Center and adjacent structures.







Figure 3: Vertical cross-section of the computational domain, illustrating the progressive mesh refinement layers within the urban canopy.

title: Urban Wind in San Carlos de Bariloche
text:
Results
Now, let’s examine some of the simulation results. Click the images below to view them in high resolution. First, we can observe the pressure distribution on the building walls alongside the streamlines of the wind approaching the Bariloche Center building. As expected, the western-facing facade bears the brunt of the wind force.






Figure 4: Pressure on building walls and streamlines of wind approaching the Bariloche Center building.





To determine if these perturbations affect the conditions at street level, we can examine the wind magnitude at 1.5 m above ground level, roughly chest-height for most people, as shown in Figure 5. Indeed, there is a clear increase in wind speed immediately adjacent to the Bariloche Center, particularly along San Martin Street. Any local resident or tourist can confirm that this “wind tunnel” effect is very real.






Figure 5: Wind speed at 1.5 m above ground.





To further illustrate this phenomenon, Figure 6 provides a street-level perspective using Street View imagery overlaid with simulated wind streamlines. This highlights another reality of this specific location: the wind on the sidewalk directly adjacent to the Bariloche Center typically rises due to significant updrafts, whereas it descends from above on the opposite sidewalk. Figure 7 confirms this behavior by displaying the vertical component of the wind at 1.5 m above ground level.






Figure 6: Wind streamlines at street-level.











Figure 7: Vertical component of wind at 1.5 m above ground.





Finally, by moving the slider below, the wind speed at different heights can be seen, revealing the extensive wake produced by the largest building in Bariloche.

  
  
  
    Height from ground: 0
    
  

  


What if?
Is there a way to mitigate these high-velocity zones? One strategy is to plant a row of tall trees (20 m high) along the sidewalk to act as a natural windbreak. To test this, I modeled the trees as a porous medium using the Darcy-Forchheimer model, applying parameters typical for the tree species found in the Bariloche area. You can see the trees zone computational mesh in the inset of Figure 8, along with the wind speed. The results are promising. By introducing these porous barriers, we can reduce wind speeds at the pedestrian level by up to 25%.






Figure 8: What if we plant a row of trees on the sidewalk?





Finally, as a fun little experiment, I fulfilled a dream shared by many of us in Bariloche. I redesigned the Bariloche Center as a 3-story building instead of 10. The result? Wind speed at the pedestrian level dropped by 50%! I will abstain from mentioning the aesthetic advantages this would also bring.






Figure 9: What if the Bariloche Center was a 3-story building?

title: Urban Wind in San Carlos de Bariloche
text:
Some remarks
So, what have we learned? While the simulations give us beautiful streamlines and precise pressure data (a bit of Colorful Fluid Dynamics never hurts), they essentially confirm what every local already knows: The Bariloche Center is a giant wind machine.
Whether you are a tourist trying to take a photo or a local just trying to get to the parques bus stop, the conclusions are clear:

The simulation demonstrates that the building does more than just block the wind. In conjunction with the structures on the opposite side of the street, it funnels high-velocity air directly onto San Martin Street at pedestrian height.
If you’ve ever felt like your hat was trying to fly to the moon while standing on the sidewalk, the vertical streamlines confirm that the building’s facade is actively trying to launch you.

Next time you are struggling to make headway past the building, just remember that it is not just you. It is a fluid dynamics phenomenon that the people of Bariloche have had to endure for over 50 years. The results shown here remark the importance of CFD as a tool for urban planning and design, especially before the construction of large, disruptive buildings.


Behind the Simulation
This project was born out of equal parts curiosity and a personal vendetta against the wind on San Martín Street. It is a deep dive into urban aerodynamics using the most iconic building (for better or worse) in Bariloche as a case study.

The workflow involved a complete CFD pipeline:

Preprocessing: Sourcing and cleaning urban CAD data and complex topography into analysis-ready STL files.
Meshing: Generating high-fidelity computational grids using snappyHexMesh.
Solving: Executing steady-state simulations within the OpenFOAM environment, with the addition of porous zones for vegetation modelling.
Post-processing: Utilizing ParaView, Python, and specialized image manipulation for results visualization.
Analysis: Interpreting local flow phenomena (such as updrafts) to quantify their impact on pedestrian comfort.
